title: Deterioration of solid insulation for thermal degradation of transformer oil
abstract: Abstract Power transformers are the most vital components of power system. Insulation used in power transformers are of insulating fluids and solid insulation system like pressboard, Kraft paper. In this work an effort has been made to investigate the detoriation of solid insulation systems for thermal degradation of transformer oil. The aging degree of solid insulation system is examined through Atomic force Microscope (AFM), Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques.

degradation of transformer oil

Received 10 June 2012; accepted 25 October 2012
Abstract: Power transformers are the most vital components of power system. Insulation used in power transformers are of
insulating ﬂuids and solid insulation system like pressboard, Kraft paper. In this work an eﬀort has been made to
investigate the detoriation of solid insulation systems for thermal degradation of transformer oil. The aging degree
of solid insulation system is examined through Atomic force Microscope (AFM), Scanning Electron Microscope
(SEM) and X-ray diﬀraction (XRD) techniques.
Keywords: Transformer • Kraft paper • Pressboard • Dielectric ﬂuid • Thermal Aging test
© Versita sp. z o.o.
1. Introduction
Power transformers are the complex part of the power sys-
tem. It is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of
transformer during operating conditions. Condition mon-
itoring of transformer helps us to assess the remaining
life time of the power transformer. One of the monitoring
methodologies is to estimate the strength of the solid insu-
lation systems for thermal degradation of transformer oil.
Rui-Jin Liao et al. [1] presented an investigation method-
ology to analyze the aging mechanism of insulation paper
∗E-mail: hvekarthik@gmail.com
for several weeks using Atomic force microscope, Scanning
electron microscope and X-Ray diﬀraction techniques. Ji-
aming Yan et al. [2] observed the surface products of oil-
impregnated paper during damage process caused by par-
tial discharge. T. S. R. Murthy et al. [3] analyzed the
degree of polymerization for cellulose paper by furan con-
tent in the oil using HPLC. P. Verma et al. [4] analyzed
degradation of transformer insulation paper by Scanning
electron microscope and X-Ray diﬀraction techniques for
various temperatures like 120–160 ◦C. Taro Hino et al.[5]
analyzed the detoriation of the oil-immersed papers by
the presence of CO, CO 2 and H 2O with the help of gas
chromotograph techniques. Jiaming Yan et al. [6] exam-
ined the partial discharge pattern on insulation paper us-
ing SEM, IR spectrum and X- ray photo electric eﬀect.
226

R. Karthik, T. Sree Renga Raja, T. Sudhakar
Shi-qang et al. [7] presented an accelerated thermal ag-
ing test on oil immersed pressboard for 120, 250 and 400
hours. They interpreted the Degree of polymerization and
structure through SEM images. In this paper an eﬀort has
been made to investigate the degradation of solid insula-
tion (Kraft paper – 20 hours, Press board – 100 hours) for
thermal degradation of transformer oil. The main reason
for aging of solid insulation [8, 9
] in power transformer
is inﬂuenced by thermal, electromechanical & chemical
stresses produced due to over loaded operating conditions.
Among these thermal stress leads to the major degradation
process of oil and there by detoriation of paper insulation.
So the brittleness and durability of the insulation paper is
reduced. As a result the expected life of the transformer is
reduced. Aging of liquid dielectrics is analyzed by break-
down voltage, acidity, ﬂash point, dielectric dissipation
factor and interfacial tension. Gases dissolved [10] in the
oil are monitored with the help of diagnostic techniques
like Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA). The ageing of insula-
tion paper is analyzed with the degree of polymerization,
furan content analysis and tensile strength [11–13] etc. In
order to exactly determine aging degree of solid insulation
suitable techniques like Optical microscope, Atomic force
microscope, Scanning electron microscope, Nuclear mag-
netic resonance, X-ray diﬀraction technique and Fourier
transform-Infrared spectroscopy [14] methods are used.
From the above techniques Atomic force microscope, Scan-
ning electron microscope and X-ray diﬀraction techniques
are used in this work to determine the aging degree of
Kraft paper and pressboard immersed in mineral oil.
2. Description of the Method
A synthetic based mineral oil with the density of
0.89 g/cm 3 at 29 ◦C, Max. and water content of 15 ppm
was used in this test. The Kraft paper and pressboard
made of cellulose ﬁber content was used for accelerated
thermal aging test. The Kraft paper and pressboard sat-
isﬁes IEC 60641-2 standard. The test samples were cut
to the dimension of 120 mm x 80 mm and the thickness of
the samples were about 0.5 mm for Kraft paper and 1 mm
for the pressboard which is shown in Figure 1
. The ar-
rangement of solid dielectrics, mineral oil and outlet valve
of the test chamber is shown in Figure 2
.
Initially the test samples were dried to reduce their mois-
ture content. The whole assembly of the test sample is
immersed with the mineral oil in the test cell and tempera-
ture of the test cell in maintained at 90 ◦C. The Kraft paper
and pressboard are heated up to 20 hours and 100 hours
respectively. Aging degree of Kraft paper and pressboard
is analyzed using AFM, SEM and X-RD Techniques.

Kraft Paper at 90◦C for 20 hours (c) New Pressboard (d)

3. Results and Discussion
3.1. AFM analysis
AFM instrument [15] was used to analyze the surface
of the samples. The AFM studies were conducted by
using Park systems Korea model XE70. The scanning
probe modes which scan across surface of the test samples
and a repulsive force between the tip and the samples is
recorded relative to spatial variations and then converted
into analogue images which are shown below.
The Figure 3 shows surface image of the unaged Kraft pa-
per. The scanning probe range is about 5 µm x 5 µm. The
colored surface image of the AFM provides the changes in
the surface that is from brown to white indicate the lowest
to the highest position. The meshed structure of cellulose
ﬁbers were in regular order.
The Figure 4 shows the cropped image of the unaged Kraft
paper. The meshed structure of cellulose ﬁbers were in
227
Deterioration of solid insulation for thermal degradation of transformer oil
Figure 3. Image of New Kraft Paper Surface of AFM
the range of 300 x 300 nm. The meshed structure of the
cellulose ﬁbers were viewed clearly and found no changes
in the structure. The value of the molecular units in the
unaged Kraft paper is 0–100 nm.
Figure 4. Typical Cropped Image of New Kraft Paper of AFM
The Figure 5 shows the surface images of the mineral oil
aged Kraft paper for 20 hours. The meshed structures of
cellulose ﬁbers were disordered.
The Figure 6 shows the enlarged AFM image of the min-
eral oil aged Kraft paper for 20 hours. The meshed struc-
ture of the cellulose ﬁbers were viewed clearly and found
drastic changes in the structure. The value of molecular
units in the mineral oil aged Kraft paper is reduced to
0–10 nm range.
From this we can infer that surface of Kraft paper is highly
detoriated with thermal degradation of mineral oil and
ﬁnally leading to decrease of insulation strength of the
Kraft paper.
The Figure 7 shows surface images of the unaged press-
board. The scanning probe range is about 5 µm x 5µm. The

colored surface image of the AFM provides the changes in
the surface that is from brown to white indicate the lowest
to the highest position. The meshed structure of cellulose
ﬁbers were in regular order.

The Figure 8 shows the enlarged image of the unaged
pressboard. The meshed structure of the cellulose ﬁbers
were viewed clearly and found no changes in the structure.
The value of the molecular units in the unaged pressboard
is 0–200 nm range.
Figure 8. Cropped Image of New Pressboard
The Figure 9 shows the surface AFM images of the mineral
oil aged pressboard for 100 hours. The meshed structure
of cellulose ﬁbers were in disordered form.
Figure 9. Image of Mineral Oil Aged Pressboard at 90 ◦C for 100
Hours
The Figure 10 shows the enlarged image of the mineral oil
aged pressboard for 100 hours. The meshed structure of
the cellulose ﬁbers were viewed clearly and found drastic
changes in the structure. The value of molecular units in
the mineral oil aged pressboard is reduced to 10–30 nm
range.
From this we shall infer that surface of pressboard is
highly detoriated with thermal degradation of mineral oil
and leads to decrease of insulation strength of the press-
board.
Figure 10. Cropped Image of Mineral Oil aged Pressboard of AFM
3.2. Structural analysis with SEM
Scanning electron microscope was used in order to study
the micro structural analysis of the aged Kraft paper and
pressboard samples. The SEM studies were conducted by
using HITACHI model S-3000H.
Figure 11. Typical SEM image of New Kraft Paper
The Figure 10 shows the SEM image of fresh Kraft pa-
per at x200 magniﬁcations. The SEM image indicates
that cellulose ﬁbers are tied together and closely packed.
It is found that average width of the cellulose ﬁbers is
19.59 mm. The SEM image indicates that the cellulose
ﬁbers form the chain structures and no bond breaking in
structure.
229
Deterioration of solid insulation for thermal degradation of transformer oil
Figure 12. SEM image of Mineral Oil aged Kraft Paper for 20 Hours
The Figure 12 shows the SEM image of mineral oil aged
Kraft paper for 20 hours with x200 magniﬁcations. The
image indicates the cellulose ﬁbers are found lack in order
of arrangement. The sides of the walls in the structure of
the cellulose ﬁbers are destroyed. The average width of
the cellulose ﬁbers is decreased to 19.35 mm.
Figure 13. SEM image of New Pressboard
The Figure 13 shows the SEM microscope of fresh press-
board at x200 magniﬁcations. The SEM image indicates
the cellulose ﬁbers are tied together and closely packed.
The average width of the cellulose ﬁbers is 19.05 mm.
The micrograph indicates that the cellulose ﬁbers form
the chain structures and no bond breaking in them.
Figure 14. Typical SEM Micrograph of Mineral Oil aged Pressboard
The Figure 14 shows the SEM images of mineral oil aged
pressboard with x200 magniﬁcations. The image indicates
the cellulose ﬁbers are found lack in order of arrangement.
The sides of the walls in the structure of the cellulose
ﬁbers are destroyed. The average width of the cellulose
ﬁbers is decreased to 15.65 mm. The image indicates
that the chain structures of the cellulose ﬁbers destroyed
severely and leading to the rupturing of the pressboard.
3.3. X-RAY diﬀraction method
X-ray diﬀraction technique is an analytical technique used
for identiﬁcation of crystalline material. The X-rays of
known wavelength are passed through the sample to iden-
tify the crystal structure. The X ray diﬀraction studies
were conducted by using Panalytical model ’X’ per PRO.
The wave nature is diﬀracted by crystal to give unique
pattern of peaks of ’reﬂections’ at diﬀering angles and of
diﬀering intensity. The X-ray detector moves around the
sample and measures the intensity of these peaks and
positions of these peaks.
The structure and number of atoms present in the structure
are the deciding factors of the crystalline material of the
test samples. Relative intensity of the material is analyzed
with help of the ordered peak (sharp) and disordered peak
(smooth). In addition to the relative intensity the mean
230
R. Karthik, T. Sree Renga Raja, T. Sudhakar
size of the crystalline domains can cause changes in the
crystalline material of the test samples and it is calculated
with the Scherer formula [1]. Figure 14 shows diﬀraction
pattern of the unaged Kraft paper. The relative intensity of
the unaged sample was 35.04%. The size of the crystalline
domains is 3.084 Å.
Figure 15. XRD pattern of New Kraft Paper
The Figure 16 shows diﬀraction pattern of the mineral oil
aged Kraft paper for 20 hours. The relative intensity of the
mineral oil aged paper was 14.65% and the mean size of
the crystalline domains is 1.518 Å. Hence from the above
result it is proved that the intensity of the Kraft paper is
reducing with time.
Figure 16. XRD pattern of Mineral Oil Aged Kraft Paper at 90◦C for
20 Hours
The Figure 17 shows the diﬀraction pattern of the unaged
pressboard. The relative intensity of the unaged sample
was 23.44%. The size of the crystalline domains is 2.161 Å.
The Figure 18 shows diﬀraction pattern of the mineral oil
aged pressboard for 100 hours. The relative intensity of
Figure 17. XRD pattern of New Pressboard
the mineral oil aged paper was 10.54% and the mean size
of the crystalline domains is 1.994 Å.
Figure 18. XRD pattern of Mineral Oil aged pressboard at 90◦C for
100 Hours
Hence from the above obtained results it is conferred that
the relative intensity of the pressboard is reducing with
increase in time. The Table 1 compares the test results
in all types of techniques and it is found that the surface
degrades for increase in hours of ageing.
4. Conclusions
One of the critical parameter which determines the life of
power transformer is strength of solid insulation. Insula-
tion strength of Kraft paper and pressboard is mainly de-
termined by thermal degradation of transformer oil. Deto-
riation level of solid insulation systems is examined using
AFM, SEM and XRD Techniques. Exact monitoring of
solid insulation systems surely paves way for optimized
performance of power transformers.
